So we have constructed a little plug in that you can get
for the Chrome broswer which will look at the terms and conditions and
measure that complexity for you. There is an algorithm called SMOG
which stands for simple metric gobbledygook. It allows you to
get a measure of how complex that text is and how dense that text is.
We were able to then map that
in the UK context onto

educational attainment levels.
So essentially
how much education would you have to have done in

order to be able to read the document
that complex.

The basic principle of this is that
what you do is you sample
the start of the beginning of the document and you look at particular measures
across this.
Long words, how many are small.
How long sentences are, how many secondary clauses there are.
So what you actually do is develop a set of matrix which

allow you to measure those and you combine
those metrics together

and normalize them so that you have a
measure which

shows you that these are small sentences
with small words,
big complex sentences, large paragraphs,

with large words.  What we found was that
to be able to read
the terms and conditions, in this case for the utilities companies
for the people who
supply us all with energy, it meant that you actually had to have
a tertiary level education.
So you need at least are bachelor's degree, most likely a master's
or post doctoral level of qualification.
So, you need this in order to be able to understand the density of that text.
